description: Your ability to connect design decisions to business goals, frame problems strategically, and work effectively with product managers.

scoreMeaning.strong: You connect design decisions to product metrics and business outcomes. You co-own product strategy with PMs and influence roadmaps.
scoreMeaning.decent: You understand product goals and can work with PMs, but may struggle with strategic thinking or connecting design to metrics.
scoreMeaning.needsImprovement: You focus mainly on UI craft without connecting to product strategy. You may receive requirements rather than co-creating them.

strong: Co-create problem statements and success metrics with PMs for major initiatives.
Document how design choices support product metrics and business goals.
Propose design-driven product improvements based on user insights and data.
Lead design reviews that discuss trade-offs and strategy, not just visuals.
decent: For each feature you own, identify one primary success metric with your PM.
Before starting design, write a short problem framing doc: who, what, why now.
Brainstorm at least three solution directions and compare trade-offs.
Align with PM/eng on scope and success criteria before detailed design.
needsImprovement: Ask PMs for explicit problem statements and success metrics if missing.
Learn about common product metrics (DAU, retention, conversion) and how design affects them.
Practice framing problems before jumping to solutions.
Read about product thinking and how designers work with PMs.

examplesOfStrong: You influence product roadmap through design insights and user research.
You connect design changes to measurable business outcomes.
You co-create product strategy with PMs, not just execute on requirements.
examplesOfWeak: You receive requirements and design without understanding the 'why'.
Design decisions aren't connected to product goals or metrics.
You work in isolation from product strategy and business context.
